p.s: In John Worne's newspaper article Language learning in the UK: can't, won't, don't, published in The Telegraph on 27th January in 2015, the author writes about the UK's studentsdecreaseingdecreasing interest in learning foreign languages and outlines the problems he sees with that.

John Worne begins by writing that, during the past couple of years, the numbers of British students learning a foreign language at a high level have gone down and don't look as if they were going to rise in the future.

He continues to praise the uptake of languagelearninglanguage learning at a younger age in British primary schools, but also refers to a study showing students starting a new language at grammar school have also decreased.

Next Worne disagrees with people seeing no harm in such a desinterestdisinterest with foreign languages, stating there are many reasons for foreign languages becoming crucial for the UK in the future, especially for economic and diplomaticaldiplomatic reasons.

He proceeds to refer to another study which shows that a high percentage of British businesses are looking to employ people whichwho are capable of speaking multiple languages and that the percentage will increase in the future.

John Worne follows up by saying the UK is depending on more youngsters to learn a foreign language for the future and finishes off with an appeal to british parents, asking them to get their children into foreign language learning.

To sum up John Worne writes about the continouscontinuous decrease of young people in the UK learning languages next to English, explains how he feels language skills are crucial for the future of the UK and encourages both students and parents all over the UK to consider foreign language learning as an important part of education.
